string-array.name: shortDescriptions
string-array.item: Ale is a type of beer brewed using a warm fermentation method, resulting in a sweet, full-bodied and fruity taste. Historically, the term referred to a drink brewed without hops.
Beer made from bread instead of cereal grains
A strong version of a brown beer brewed in Westmalle Abbey in 1856, which is known to have been on sale to the public by June 1861
a Belgian lambic beer that is fermented using raspberries. It is one of many modern types of fruit beer that have been inspired by the more traditional kriek beer, which is made using sour cherries
A historical style of beer from Poland that is typically made from oak-smoked wheat malt.
Belgian beer made by blending young (1-year-old) and old (2- to 3-year-old) lambics, which is bottled for a second fermentation.
A type of alcoholic beverage and craft beer that is manufactured in the style of a soft drink.
A beer that has undergone some degree of fractional freezing during production
A hoppy beer style within the broader category of pale ale
A beer which has been brewed and conditioned at low temperature.
A type of beer brewed in the Pajottenland region of Belgium southwest of Brussels and in Brussels itself since the 13th century.
A beer, usually a pale lager, that is reduced in alcohol content or in calories compared to regular beers
A beer with high alcohol content
Also known as Flanders Brown, is a style of beer originating from the Flemish region of Belgium
A type of pale lager. It takes its name from the Bohemian city of Pilsen (Plze≈à), where it was first produced in 1842 by Bavarian brewer Josef Groll.
A style of beer that was developed in London, England in the early eighteenth century.[1] It was well-hopped and dark in appearance owing to the use of brown malt
Rye beer refers to any beer in which rye (generally malted) is substituted for some portion of the barley.
A pale ale that is highly carbonated, fruity, spicy, and often bottle conditioned
Sour beer is beer which has an intentionally acidic, tart, or sour taste. Traditional sour beer styles include Belgian lambics, gueuze and Flanders red ale, and German gose
Stout is a dark, top-fermented beer with a number of variations, including dry stout, oatmeal stout, milk stout, and imperial stout.
Wheat beer is a top-fermented beer which is brewed with a large proportion of wheat relative to the amount of malted barley.
